metadata.title: Rheological behavior characteristics of TiO2-MWCNT/10w40 hybrid nano-oil affected by temperature, concentration and shear rate_ An experimental study and a neural network simulating

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Physica E
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/physe
Rheological behavior characteristics of TiO2-MWCNT/10w40 hybrid nano-oil affected by temperature, concentration and shear rate: An experimental study and a neural network simulating
Mohammad Hemmat Esfea,⁎, Hossein Rostamianb, Mohammad Reza Sarlaka, Mousa Rejvanic, Ali Alirezaiec
a Department of Mechanical Engineering, Imam Hossein University, Tehran, Iran b Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Semnan University, Semnan, Iran c Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Semnan University, Semnan, Iran
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Nano-oil, rheological behavior Dynamic viscosity Neural network Non-Newtonian fluids
A B S T R A C T
In this article, rheological behavior of TiO2-MWCNT (45–55%)/10w40 hybrid nano-oil was studied experimentally. The nano- oils were tested at temperature ranges of 5–55 °C and in shear rates up to 11,997 s−1. With respect to viscosity, shear stress and shear rate variations it was cleared that either of the base oil and nano-oil were non-Newtonian fluids. New equations which were based on thickness of the fluid were presented for different temperature values, R-squared values were between 0.9221 and 0.9998 (the precise of correlation changes depend on temperature). Also to predict the nano-oil behavior, neural network method was utilized. an artificial neural network (MLP type) were used to predict the viscosity in terms of temperature, solid volume fraction and shear stress. to compare the prediction precise of neural network and correlation the results of these two were compared with together. ANN showed more accurate results in comparison with correlation results. R2 and (MSE) were 0.9979 and 0.000016 respectively for the ANN.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Oils play an important role in most of heat transfer and engineering systems such as blood flow in the veins, so the act of improving the characteristics of oils can modify these systems to have higher performances [1]. The most important mechanical characteristics which should be improved in order to modify systems performance are viscosity, rheological properties and heat transfer characteristics. To do so adding nanoparticles into the base oil is one of the most appropriate solutions which is also relatively cost effective. Although using nanofluids is useful when the favorable effect on thermal conductivity is greater than unfavorable effect on dynamic viscosity [2– 11]. many experiments have done to introduce a more efficient nanofluid [12–21].
Viscosity of water based TiO2 nanofluids has decrement with temperature [22]. Some experimental models and correlation for prediction of viscosity variation [23–29] thermal conductivity [30– 34] and rheological properties [35–41] were developed. Lately, some studies were conducted on modeling of thermal conductivity and dynamic viscosity of nanofluids [42–51]. For this purpose, artificial
neural network was applied. Based on the results of all the studies, ANN has good precision to predict thermos-physical properties of nanofluid and is a strong method for modeling. It has observed in TiO2–MWCNT/water based nanofluid that viscosity has enhancement with TiO2 nanoparticle increasing. The decoration of Multiwall Carbon Nanotube determine the dilatant behavior [51]. MWCNT- Waterethylene glycol 0.9 wt% has the most enhancement in thermal conductivity. The specific heat of nanofluids has decrement with volume fraction [52]. The rheological analysis showed that the transition region from shear thinning to Newtonian extended to the higher shear stress range compared to that of base fluids [53,54]. The thermal conductivity and dynamic viscosity of diamond &MWCNT/oil base fluid has enhancement with particle dispersed in nanofluid [55]. In Table 1 summarized of some experimental studies for the viscosity of nanofluids containing TiO2, MWCNT, oil with different base fluid.
Surveying in about rheological behavior studies of nanofluids revealed that TiO2-MWCNT (45–55%)/10w40 hybrid nano-lubricant has not been investigated up to now. In this study, the rheological behavior of the hybrid nano-lubricant was evaluated at various temperatures, solid volume fractions and shear rates. A new correlation

was proposed to predict dynamic viscosity of nano-lubricant, also the rheological behavior was predicted by using neural network.

sections.heading: 2. Experimentation
sections.text:
TiO2-MWCNT/10W40 hybrid nano-oil was made out of combination of 10W40 engine oil with a nanoparticles compound which consisted of 45% TiO2 of 30 nm diameter and 55% of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNT) with inner diameter of 2–6 nm and outer diameter of 5–20 nm. Nanoparticles sizes are extracted by X-ray diffraction diagram of Fig. 1.
Physicochemical properties of TiO2 nanoparticles and MWCNTs are listed in Tables 2 and 3. In this study the nanoparticles were dispersed in 10W40 engine oil, the specifications of which are shown in Table 4. All used nanoparticles are manufactured in US Research
Nanomaterials Inc., the advanced nanomaterial company. In order to make the hybrid nano-oil, firstly the various portions of
nanoparticles were calculated using Eq. (1).

Then they were added to a predetermined volume of the base oil and the solutions were mixed for 2 hours. An ultrasonic blender made by (Ultrasonic Homogenizer, Development of Ultrasonic Technology, Iran)was utilized for 5-7 hours in order to remove agglomerations of nanoparticles. Fig. 2 illustrates some samples of TiO2, MWCNT, 10W40 oil and the obtained nano-oil.

sections.heading: 2.1. Viscosity measurement
sections.text:
Fig. 3 illustrates the apparatus which was used for measuring viscosity values of the samples. CAP 2000+ viscometer made by (Brookfield Engineering Laboratories, Inc.) with ± 2.0% accuracy and repeatability of ± 0.5% was used for measuring viscosity. This appara-
Property Value
Kinematic viscosity @ 100 °C 14.81 cSt Viscosity Index (VI) 160 Minimum flash point 232 °C Minimum pour point −24 °C Density @ 15 °C 873 (kg/m3)
tus is specifically designed for measuring viscosity of fluids with moderate and high shear rates. The measurements were carried out for shear rate ranges of 666.65 up to 11,999.7 and for volume fractions of .05%, 0.1%, 0.25%, 0.5%, 0.75% and 1% at temperatures between 5 and 55 °C.

sections.heading: 3.1. Rheological behavior surveying
sections.text:
In Fig. 4 rheological behavior of the nano-oil with 1% volume fraction of nanoparticles is compared with neat 10W40 oil at various temperatures. With respect to these diagrams, regardless of temperature when shear rate is increased, shear stress value does not vary linearly. This signifies that both of the base oil and the nano-oil are non-Newtonian fluids.
Shear stress is calculated by the use of Eq. (2) for non-Newtonian fluids which are also called power-law fluids:
τ mγ= ṅ (2)
The governing equation for apparent viscosity in non-Newtonian fluids is presented below:
μ mγ= ˙app n−1 (3)
where, τ is the shear stress, γ ̇ is the shear rate, m is consistency index, n is the power law index (n < 1) and µ is the apparent viscosity. For a further precise study on TiO2-MWCNT (45–55%) /10w40 hybrid nanooil characteristics, power law and consistency indexes are respectively listed in Tables 5 and 6.
According to Table 5 all of the n indexes are less than 1 which signifies that the hybrid nano-oil was a non-Newtonian fluid with shear thinning behavior, regardless of temperature and volume fraction.
Power law indexes in terms of thickness are presented in Fig. 5 for various temperatures. As it can be seen at temperatures between 5 and 45 °C, adding nanoparticles to the base oil does not change the behavior of the hybrid nano-oil dramatically, as variation of power law indexes are nearly 0.04 which signifies that the effects of thickness are negligible. This is quite different at the temperature of 55 °C, as with increment of nanoparticles loading, n index is increased and its value for the sample of 1% volume fraction is considerably more than n value for 0% volume fraction. Fluctuations of n index curve indicate that the increment of thickness at 55 °C results in drastic changes of nano-oil behavior.
Fig. 6 illustrates consistency indexes based on thickness at various temperatures. According to this figure the value of m index is increased as a result of thickness enhancement but it is totally different at the
temperature of 55 °C that the m index is reduced. Consistency index enhancement signifies increment of apparent
viscosity and its cause can be explained by the fact of random movement of dispersed nanoparticles in a base fluid. Van der Waals forces between the nanoparticles and the base oil form clusters of nanoparticles resulting in viscosity increment due to limited mobility of the nanoparticles.
The effect of temperature on the hybrid nano-oil at a constant shear rate is presented in Fig. 7. Increasing of temperature results in nanoparticles movement which is associated with reducing of the fluid resistance over being flown, therefore viscosity is reduced.
As a result of increasing in nanoparticles loading in the base fluid, the internal shear stress increases and this is associated with friction enhancement in the fluid that makes it able to resist more against flowing which is synonymous with viscosity enhancement.

sections.heading: 3.2. Proposed correlation
sections.text:
In order to predict viscosity data of TiO2-MWCNT (45–55%)/ 10W40, Einstein [61] and Wang et al. [62] theoretical equations were utilized. The results are illustrated in Fig. 8.
As it can be seen, the theoretical equations are not capable of predicting viscosity in any of volume fraction or temperature conditions. Therefore, by using curve fitting technique on the experimental
data in terms of a constant temperature, a new quadratic equation was derived based on the thickness of the hybrid nano-oil for the purpose of viscosity prediction. this polynomial correlation is choosed between too many correlations because of its closer amount of R2 to 1 between all correlations. on the other hand the most common correlations that is in use for curve fitting are polynomial correlations like Eq. (4).

proposal equation, error diagram is depicted in Fig. 9. According to this figure it is clearly observed that most of the data are laid on the bisector line and the others are in its near proximity.
Fig. 10 shows the margin of errors. These values are all calculated using Eq. (5).

According to this figure the highest calculated error is almost equal to 1.1% and it occurred at the temperature of 55 °C and volume fraction of 1%. Since the errors are nearly zero, it is concluded that the
predicted viscosity values are very close to the actual values for volume fractions of 0.25% and 0.5%.

sections.heading: 3.3. ANN modeling
sections.text:
The main objective of this study at this section was to obtain the pattern of nanofluid dynamic viscosity changes based on variables of temperature, volume fraction, and shear rate, with modeling of the empirical data. With using the available empirical data of different volume fractions of nanoparticles, various temperature points and different shear rates, the most appropriate technique for modeling of the empirical data, which has an excellent precision, is using of neural networks. In order to use neural networks, the input data must be inserted first; the networks divide the data into 3 sections of training data, validation data, and test data, after the data is preprocessed. In order to put data into the first layer neurons, a weight and a bias value are determined. After passing of the data through each layer’s neurons, the extracted values are compared with the empirical values of viscosity. If the error value is not within the acceptable range, this process is iterated with different values of weight. Otherwise, training stops and makes the network structure to be fixed. Fig. 11 shows a summary of this process.
The specifications of the neural network which was used in the present paper are shown in Table 8. Regarding to this table the neural networks exhibited an excellent accuracy as R2 value of 99.79% was obtained.
Error values for all data are depicted in Fig. 12 in terms of number of data. According to this figure most of the error values are laid on or in proximity of the bisector line so mean squared error (MSE) is 0.0000161.
Error values of the predicted data using neural network with the actual viscosity values are depicted in Fig. 13. According to this figure the highest error is 0.08.
The outstanding accuracy of neural network modeling can be observed in Fig. 14 in which the experimental data of viscosity are compared with neural network outputs. Fig. 15 illustrates a comparison between the diagrams for various temperature and thickness values in a constant shear rate. Regarding to this diagrams, the neural network was astonishingly capable of predicting viscosity of TiO2MWCNT (45–55%)/10W40 nano-oil.
In Fig. 15 the outputs of neural network modeling and correlation are compared with the empirical viscosity data at various temperatures. According to the diagrams, the neural network worked exceptionally for prediction of data and its outputs are in good accordance with
experimental viscosity data. But correlation has errors, mainly for lower volume fractions and higher temperature.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this study, firstly rheological behavior of a nano-oil was determined empirically and then an equation was presented by which this behavior can be predicted. Also neural network modeling was utilized for the purpose of prediction. To do so a hybrid nano-oil consisted of TiO2 nanoparticles with mean diameter of 30 nm and MWCTNs with inner diameter of 2–6 nm and outer diameter of 5– 20 nm. TiO2 nanoparticles and MWCNTs were mixed with the proportion of 45% and 55% respectively and they were dispersed in volume fractions of 0.05, 0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75 and 1. The measurements were conducted at the temperatures between 5 and 55 °C and in shear rate values within 666.5 up to 11,997.
The results signified that the TiO2-MWCNT/10W40 hybrid nano-oil was a non-Newtonian fluid with shear thinning behavior. According to the Ostwald–de Waele equation, power law and consistency indexes were obtained and their variations in terms of temperature and thickness were discussed afterward. Consistency index reduced by temperature enhancement and it was incremented by increasing in thickness of the nano-oil. Also with respect to power law index it was observed that with changing in thickness of the fluid, behavior of the hybrid nano-oil does not vary significantly, but at the temperature of 55 °C the non-Newtonian behavior
of the nano-oil was affected by the thickness and it was occasionally increased or decreased. When the experimental data is compared with the theoretical models, it is clearly observable that none of the models was capable of an appropriate prediction of the nano-oil behavior; therefore, curve fitting technique was utilized for achieving a new governing equation. The new equation was capable of predicting experimental data
as R2 values for the equation were calculated between 0.9221 and 0.9998. On the other hand, behavior of the hybrid nano-oil was verified with neural network modeling. The results signify that the output data of ANN are in good accordance with viscosity data. Neural network was more successful for data prediction as its R2 and MSE were 0.9979 and 0.000016 respectively.

referenceMentions.context: Oils play an important role in most of heat transfer and engineering systems such as blood flow in the veins, so the act of improving the characteristics of oils can modify these systems to have higher performances [1].
Viscosity of water based TiO2 nanofluids has decrement with temperature [22].

metadata.abstractText: In this article, rheological behavior of TiO2-MWCNT (45–55%)/10w40 hybrid nano-oil was studied experimentally. The nanooils were tested at temperature ranges of 5–55 °C and in shear rates up to 11,997 s. With respect to viscosity, shear stress and shear rate variations it was cleared that either of the base oil and nano-oil were non-Newtonian fluids. New equations which were based on thickness of the fluid were presented for different temperature values, R-squared values were between 0.9221 and 0.9998 (the precise of correlation changes depend on temperature). Also to predict the nano-oil behavior, neural network method was utilized. an artificial neural network (MLP type) were used to predict the viscosity in terms of temperature, solid volume fraction and shear stress. to compare the prediction precise of neural network and correlation the results of these two were compared with together. ANN showed more accurate results in comparison with correlation results. R and (MSE) were 0.9979 and 0.000016 respectively for the ANN.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
